newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan dollar closes sharply up on rebound.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan dollar closes sharply up on rebound.

text.p: The Taiwan dollar finished sharply higher on Wednesday after falling to a seven-month low on Tuesday, dealers said.
The local unit ended at T$27.583, back from an intra-day high of T$27.580, against Tuesday's T$27.648 close.
Turnover through dealers was a hectic US$430.5 million.
Dealers attributed the Taiwan dollar's sharp Wednesday rebound in part to tight liquidity in the banking system and partly because of the U.S. dollar's corrections overseas.
"Liquidity demand for the Taiwan dollar is very strong today, prompting many people to sell their U.S. dollar positions," said one dealer at a foreign bank.
The short-term money rates soared on Wednesday.
The overnight interbank rate in late afternoon was at 6.454 percent against Tuesday's 5.986 close, with the 30-day commercial paper jumping to 6.75-7.00 against 5.75.
Dealers said the Taiwan dollar's movements on Thursday will largely depend on the overnight announcement of U.S. trade data.
A volatile range of T$27.55-27.70 was seen for Thursday.
